indicators.justification:
No beneficial ownership data is available. Company data is available on BizPortal (1) which is administered by CIPC, an independent body established through the Companies Act of 2008 (2). However, to access the data, one needs to sign up either using a South African identity number or using login details given to them if they have signed up for any other service offered by CIPC. So, if one does not have an SA identity number, or has not signed up for other CIPC services, they cannot access the data. In addition, even though the Companies Act of 2008 specifies that this information should be updated regularly, it is also impossible to verify if the data is regularly updated since this detail is not available. 

Sources:
(1)https://bizportal.gov.za/bizprofile.aspx
(2)https://www.gov.za/sites/default/files/gcis_document/201409/321214210.pdf

indicators.justification:
Results from public participation processes are meant to availed to participants and published on a relevant ministry's website as mentioned in the Public Participation Framework prepared by the South African Legislative Sector (1). However, an online search of any such results being published has yielded no instances. However, a related instance regarding the passing of the Medicines and Related Substances Amendment Act of 2015 revealed that affected stakeholders were not consulted and when the draft act was published, it was challenged (2). The indication is that whilst frameworks do exist that mangate public participation in making laws, including in the constitution, to agreater extent public participation is not being practiced by legislative units in South Africa. A study done by the Department of Public Service and Administration in 2008 confirmed this (1)

Sources

(1)https://www.sals.gov.za/docs/pubs/ppf.pdf
(2)https://www.financialinstitutionslegalsnapshot.com/2019/01/public-participation-in-south-african-law-making-process-is-essential/
(3)http://www.dpsa.gov.za/dpsa2g/documents/cdw/2014/citizenengagement.pdf

indicators.justification:
South Africa does not have an open data policy in place, although high profile commitments have been made to eventually have one. Such a policy would most likely be a primary driver for government to provide support for data reuse. The biggest indications so far that such an environment will soon be cultivated by the South African Government are the National Digital and Future Skills Strategy (1) and the Draft National Policy on Data and Cloud (2). These were only released in 2021 and 2020 respectively. In this regard, minimal or no headway has been made by the government with respect to actually supporting data reuse.

No official government policy or strategy was found which caters for data literacy training for civil servants. The only item found to somehow refer to data literacy was the National Digital and Future Skills Strategy released in September 2020 (1). However, the strategy does not explicitly refer to data literacy training for civil servants. Instead, it refers mainly to enhancing digital skills (including data literacy) for the greater population of South Africa in order for the country to be well-positioned to effectively participate in the 4IR (1). With regards to this, the strategy seems to be more geared towards school curriculums and tertiary education.

indicators.justification:
There is no data sharing policy/framework in South Africa, nor is there any draft law/regulation in force serving the purpose of specifying data sharing policies. However, the draft National Data and Cloud Policy published in April 2021 does specify a policy intervention for the establishment of a national open data policy/framework which is stated will address data sharing and interoperability. 

In my extended search for data sharing amongst national departments institutions, I did come across the South African National Biodiversity (SANBI) which was established under the National Environmental Management Act, No. 10 of 2004 (1). The SANBI has its own data sharing policy between itself and its partners, which is probably driver by one of its clear mandates to "Collect, generate process, coordinate and disseminate information about biodiversity and sustainable use of indigenous biological resources and maintain databases" (1). As far as I can tell, they are the only national body that has a clear data sharing policy.

indicators.justification:
The POPIA (1) and the PAIA (2) comprehensively provide frameworks for the protection of personal information as provided in the justifications given under each response. South Africa had to develop a comprehensive framework through the POPIA as the government sought to facilitate the participation of the country's industry in the growing global electronic trade (3). The South African Law Commission was tasked with investigating the country's privacy and data protection policy. The commission's investigation resulted in a report in 2009 in which the recommendation was that privacy and information protection be regulated by a general statute (4). The POPIA was then signed into law in 2013 and eventually enacted into practice on the 1st of July in 2020 (5). Public and private entities were given a year to fully comply with the POPIA by 01 July 2021 (5). The instruments for facilitating the protection of personal information are in place in South Africa. However, it is still quite early to assess how effective they are.

indicators.justification:
There is no explicit open data policy put in place by the South African Government. Nonetheless, high-level commitments have been made by the government, pledging to develop an open data policy and environment in South Africa (1). South Africa has also not endorsed the International Open Data Charter, although efforts are being made to rectify this, such as the revision of SA's ICT policy, detailed in The ICT Policy Review Report of 2015, which explicitly recommends that "an open data policy must be developed based on recognised open data principles" (2). Following up on this development, the National Integrated ICT Policy White Paper was published in September 2016, which states that it aims to "provide the framework for implementing Government's commitment to open governance and open data" (3).
